name: Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy (THz-TDS)
summary: Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy (THz-TDS) is a non-contact, non-destructive analytical technique that uses electromagnetic radiation in the terahertz frequency range (0.1-10 THz, λ = 30 μm - 3 mm) to probe the structural, chemical, and electronic properties of materials. Unlike traditional spectroscopy that measures intensity versus frequency, THz-TDS directly measures the electric field amplitude and phase of coherent terahertz pulses transmitted through or reflected from a sample as a function of time. Fourier transformation of the time-domain signal yields complex-valued frequency-domain spectra, providing both absorption (real) and refractive index (imaginary) information simultaneously. The terahertz region is sensitive to rotational and vibrational modes in molecules, lattice vibrations in crystals, and free carrier dynamics in semiconductors, while also penetrating many dielectric materials (paper, textiles, ceramics, dried paint). In cultural heritage, THz-TDS enables subsurface imaging of multi-layer structures (paintings, murals, manuscripts), identification of pigments and materials through spectral fingerprinting, detection of hidden features (underdrawings, pentimenti, text), and characterization of degradation without contact or ionizing radiation.
keyApplications: Subsurface imaging of multi-layer paintings (revealing underdrawings, pentimenti, hidden signatures)
Non-invasive examination of manuscripts and documents (hidden text, palimpsests, watermarks)
Pigment and binder identification through THz spectral fingerprinting
Stratigraphy analysis of paint layers (thickness, composition, interfaces)
Detection of moisture, salts, and degradation products in porous materials
Examination of mummies and organic remains (non-ionizing alternative to X-ray)
Analysis of ceramics, faience, and glass (composition, manufacturing defects)
Documentation of textile and paper structure (fiber orientation, density, defects)

fundamentalPhysics.principle: THz-TDS exploits ultrafast laser pulses to generate and detect coherent terahertz electromagnetic radiation. Generation: femtosecond laser pulse (800 nm, ~100 fs duration) illuminates photoconductive antenna or nonlinear crystal, producing single-cycle THz pulse (~1 ps duration, 0.1-3 THz bandwidth). This THz pulse propagates through or reflects from sample. Detection: time-delayed portion of same laser pulse gates a second photoconductive antenna, sampling the THz electric field at different time delays via optical rectification or electro-optic sampling. Scanning the time delay (using motorized delay stage) maps out the complete THz waveform E(t) with sub-picosecond resolution. Fourier transform yields complex frequency spectrum Ẽ(ω) = |E(ω)|e^(iφ(ω)), providing both amplitude and phase. Comparing sample spectrum to reference (no sample) yields absorption coefficient α(ω) and refractive index n(ω). These material-specific optical constants reveal molecular structure, lattice dynamics, and sample morphology.
fundamentalPhysics.physicalPhenomenon: Terahertz radiation interacts with matter through several mechanisms: (1) Molecular rotations and vibrations: molecules with permanent dipole moments (water, organics) have rotational transitions in THz range (0.3-3 THz for small molecules). Lattice phonons (collective vibrations in crystals) absorb at characteristic frequencies. (2) Free carrier absorption: mobile charge carriers in semiconductors/metals absorb THz (Drude model); conductivity determines absorption. (3) Intermolecular vibrations: hydrogen bonding, van der Waals interactions produce low-frequency modes in THz. (4) Penetration: THz radiation penetrates dielectrics (paper, paint, ceramics) but is strongly absorbed by water (polar), metals (conductive), and salts (ionic resonances). Depth penetration: mm to cm in dry non-conductive materials, <100 μm in water-rich materials. Spatial resolution: diffraction-limited, ~λ/2 ≈ 150 μm - 1.5 mm (far inferior to visible/IR but superior to microwave).

equations.latex: $$E_{sample}(\omega) = E_{ref}(\omega) \cdot T(\omega) \cdot e^{-i\omega n(\omega) d / c}$$

fundamentalPhysics.interactionDepth: THz-TDS can probe subsurface layers to depths of 100 μm - 10 mm depending on material properties. Penetration depth δ = 1/α where α is absorption coefficient. Non-polar, dry materials (paper, dried paint, ceramics) are relatively transparent (low α), enabling deep penetration. Polar materials (water, alcohols) and conductors (metals, salts) strongly absorb THz, limiting penetration to surface (<100 μm). Dry paper and parchment: 1-10 mm (multi-sheet penetration), low water content → transparent; can image through ~10-20 sheets. Dried oil paint (lean): 0.5-5 mm (multiple layers), depends on pigment; lead white, ochres relatively transparent; carbon black opaque. Tempera and fresco: 0.2-2 mm, aqueous binders; if fully dried, moderately transparent. Textiles (dry cotton, linen, silk): 5-20 mm (multiple fabric layers), low absorption enables seeing through layers. Ceramics and pottery: 1-10 mm, depends on composition and porosity; glazes may be opaque if metallic. Moist materials (wet paint, humid paper): <100 μm, water strongly absorbs THz (>100 cm⁻¹ at 1 THz); surface only. Metals and graphite: <1 μm (skin depth), highly reflective; THz does not penetrate conductors. Salts (NaCl, gypsum, efflorescence): <50 μm, ionic materials absorb strongly via lattice resonances.
fundamentalPhysics.spatialResolution: Lateral Resolution: 150 μm - 1.5 mm (diffraction-limited; depends on frequency and focusing optics). Depth Resolution: 10-100 μm (depends on pulse duration and material dispersion). Limiting factors: Wavelength (0.03-3 mm): diffraction limits lateral resolution to ~λ/2, Pulse duration (~1 ps): limits temporal (depth) resolution to ~300 μm in free space, Material dispersion: pulse broadening in sample degrades depth resolution, Signal-to-noise ratio: weak signals limit ability to resolve small features, Scattering: rough interfaces, heterogeneous materials scatter THz (reduce penetration/resolution), Water absorption: moisture in sample attenuates signal, limiting depth and resolution.
fundamentalPhysics.detectionLimit: Thin layer detection: ~10-50 μm thickness (if sufficient refractive index contrast). Material identification: ~1-5% concentration for strongly absorbing species in matrix. Dynamic range: 10³-10⁴ in amplitude (30-40 dB in power) typical for commercial systems; can reach 10⁵-10⁶ (50-60 dB) with optimization. Signal-to-noise: SNR 1000:1 to 10,000:1 achievable for strong reflectors; degrades for weak signals (thin layers, low contrast).

instrumentation.source: THz generation: (1) Photoconductive antenna (most common), or (2) Optical rectification in nonlinear crystal (ZnTe, GaP, DAST). Pump laser: Ti:sapphire or fiber laser (800 nm or 1550 nm, 100 fs pulses, 80-100 MHz rep rate, 10-100 mW average power). THz output: broadband pulse (0.1-4 THz typical), peak field 1-100 kV/cm, average power 1-100 μW. THz photon energy: 0.4-40 meV (0.1-10 THz), corresponding to 4-400 cm⁻¹ or λ = 30 μm - 3 mm. Average THz power: 1-100 μW (peak power during pulse: mW-level but 100 fs duration → low average). Pulsed (single-cycle pulses, ~1 ps duration); coherent (phase-stable); broadband (octave-spanning spectrum); Gaussian beam profile.
instrumentation.detector: Photoconductive antenna (gated detection), Electro-optic sampling (in ZnTe, GaP crystal), or Bolometer (incoherent detection, less common for TDS). Sensitive to 0.1-10 THz (limited by generation bandwidth and detector response). Quantum efficiency ~10⁻⁶-10⁻⁴ for photoconductive detection (very low, but coherent detection enables high SNR via lock-in). Time resolution: Sub-picosecond (limited by laser pulse width and gate pulse duration; <100 fs achievable).
instrumentation.optics: Femtosecond laser (Ti:sapphire or fiber laser), Beam splitter (divide pump and probe beams), Optical delay line (motorized stage, 0-300 ps delay range), THz emitter (photoconductive antenna or nonlinear crystal), THz optics (off-axis parabolic mirrors, polyethylene lenses), Sample stage (XY motorized for imaging, Z for focusing), THz detector (photoconductive antenna or electro-optic crystal), Lock-in amplifier (phase-sensitive detection), Computer control and data acquisition. Beam path: Pump beam → emitter → THz pulse → parabolic mirror (collimate) → sample → parabolic mirror (focus) → detector ← probe beam (time-delayed). Transmission or reflection geometry. Off-axis parabolic mirrors (Au-coated) focus THz to spot size 0.5-3 mm (depends on frequency and f-number).
criticalComponents: Stable femtosecond laser (amplitude and timing stability critical for coherent detection)
Precision optical delay line (sub-μm positioning accuracy, 0-300 ps range)
High-efficiency THz emitter/detector pair (photoconductive antennas with optimized bias and laser power)
Low-loss THz optics (parabolic mirrors preferred over lenses; avoid water vapor absorption in beam path)
Dry air or N₂ purge (eliminate water vapor absorption, which has strong lines at 1.1, 1.7, 2.5 THz)
Vibration isolation (mechanical stability essential for μm-scale alignment)
Lock-in amplifier (phase-sensitive detection recovers weak signals from noise)
Motorized sample stage (automated 2D/3D raster scanning for imaging)
instrumentation.typicalConfiguration: **Standard transmission THz-TDS:** Ti:sapphire laser (800 nm, 80 MHz, 100 fs pulses, 500 mW). 80:20 beam splitter: 80% to emitter (photoconductive antenna biased at 20-50 V), 20% to probe arm. Delay line: retroreflector on motorized stage (300 mm travel, 2 ps range). THz beam collimated and focused by 90° off-axis parabolic mirrors (f = 50-100 mm, spot size ~2 mm at focus). Sample on motorized XY stage at focus. Transmitted THz collected by second parabolic mirror, focused onto detector antenna. Lock-in amplifier (ref: laser rep rate or chopped emitter bias). Dry air purge (RH < 5%) or N₂ flow enclosure. Acquisition: scan delay 0-50 ps in 50 fs steps (1000 points), 10 ms integration per point → 10 sec per waveform. 2D imaging: 50 × 50 pixels, 10 sec/pixel → 7 hours (or faster with reduced integration).

Position sample on motorized XY stage at THz focus
For transmission: sample should be perpendicular to beam (use alignment laser)
Flat samples: mount on low-absorption holder (HDPE, quartz window)
Curved objects: may require rotation stage or reflection geometry
No pressure or contact needed (non-contact measurement)
No preparation required for most heritage objects (non-invasive)
Clean surface (remove dust) with soft brush if needed
Avoid moisture (wet cleaning) before measurement - water absorbs THz strongly
For very rough surfaces: reflection mode better than transmission (specular reflection component)
Not required - THz-TDS is non-invasive subsurface technique
However, if destructive cross-section available (from conservation sampling), can correlate THz findings with optical microscopy, SEM, etc.

Dust/particles: scatter THz if size comparable to wavelength (mm-scale). Remove with gentle cleaning
Fingerprints: oils and residues on sample surface can affect THz transmission (absorption, scattering). Handle with gloves
Condensation: cold sample in humid environment → water film forms, blocks THz. Equilibrate sample to room temperature before measurement
methodology.measurementProtocol:
**STEP 1: System Preparation and Purge (30-60 minutes)**
- Power on femtosecond laser (warm-up 30-60 min for stability)
- Activate dry air or N₂ purge system (flow ~10-20 L/min through beam path enclosure)
- Monitor humidity: aim for <5% RH in THz path (use hygrometer)
- Verify laser output stable (power, spectrum)
- Align THz emitter and detector with laser beams (optimize coupling, maximize THz signal)
- Critical parameters: Laser stable (power fluctuations <1%), Humidity <5% in THz path, THz signal optimized (check reference waveform)

**STEP 2: Reference Measurement (No Sample) (10-30 seconds per waveform)**
- With no sample in beam path, acquire reference THz waveform
- Scan optical delay over full range (0-50 ps typical)
- Record E_ref(t): THz electric field vs. time
- Typical parameters: 1000 time points (50 fs steps), 10-50 ms integration per point
- Save reference waveform (will be used to normalize sample measurement)
- Verify reference quality: strong main pulse, minimal ringing, good SNR (>1000:1 for peak)
- Critical parameters: Reference SNR >1000:1, Pulse shape clean (minimal etalon effects), Reproducible (repeat acquisition shows <1% variation)

**STEP 3: Sample Positioning and Alignment (5-15 minutes)**
- Place sample on stage at THz focus
- Use alignment laser (visible, co-aligned with THz) to position sample
- For transmission: sample perpendicular to beam; verify transmitted beam still reaches detector
- For reflection: adjust sample angle (typically 45° or normal incidence with beam splitter)
- Use motorized XY stage to locate region of interest
- Perform coarse Z-scan (along beam axis) to find optimal focus (maximum transmitted signal for transmission, or specular reflection for reflection mode)
- Critical parameters: Sample at focus (Z position optimized), Sample alignment good (beam centered, angle correct), Transmitted/reflected signal detected

**STEP 4: Sample Measurement (Single Point Spectroscopy) (10-30 seconds per position)**
- With sample in place, acquire THz waveform
- Scan delay over same range as reference
- Record E_sample(t)
- Use same integration time as reference for direct comparison
- Inspect waveform: compare to reference - note time shift (indicates refractive index), amplitude reduction (absorption), and pulse shape changes (dispersion)
- If signal too weak (<10% of reference), sample may be too thick or too absorbing (try thinner sample, different position, or reflection mode)
- Critical parameters: Sufficient transmitted signal (>1% of reference minimum), Time shift visible (confirms sample in beam), No clipping or saturation

**STEP 5: 2D/3D Imaging (Optional, for Spatial Mapping, 1-24 hours)**
- Define scan area (e.g., 50 × 50 mm) and pixel size (0.5-2 mm step)
- Motorized stage rasters sample under fixed THz beam
- At each pixel, acquire full THz waveform (10-30 sec)
- Total time: N_pixels × t_per_pixel (e.g., 100×100 pixels × 10 sec = 28 hours; often use faster parameters: 50×50 × 5 sec = 2 hours)
- Save 3D data cube: E(x,y,t)
- Monitor progress; pause/resume if needed
- Can extract specific time slices (depth-resolved imaging) or integrate full pulse (transmission contrast)
- Critical parameters: Sample stable (no drift during long scan), Consistent SNR across scan area, Data size manageable (100×100×1000 points = 10 MB, reasonable)

**STEP 6: Spectral Calibration (Optional, 15-30 minutes)**
- If absolute spectroscopic quantification needed: measure calibration samples with known thickness and refractive index (e.g., HDPE, quartz plate)
- Compare measured transmission to calculated (Fresnel equations) to validate system calibration
- Check for systematic errors (etalon effects, misalignment)
- Apply corrections if needed

**STEP 7: Multi-Position or Multi-Sample Measurement (Variable, hours to days for large studies)**
- Move to next region of interest or load next sample
- Repeat steps 3-5
- For comparative studies: maintain consistent measurement conditions (laser power, integration time, purge quality) across all samples
- Acquire new reference periodically (every 30-60 min) to account for slow drifts in laser or environment

**STEP 8: Post-Measurement Documentation (10-20 minutes)**
- Record metadata: sample ID, measurement locations (photograph with marked positions), environmental conditions (T, RH), system parameters (laser power, integration time)
- Save all waveforms and images
- Export data for offline processing and analysis

methodology.calibration:
**Standards used:** HDPE (high-density polyethylene) plate: known thickness (1-3 mm), n ≈ 1.53 (weakly dispersive), low absorption, Quartz plate: known thickness, n ≈ 2.1, well-characterized THz properties, Air/vacuum: reference measurement (no sample), Metal mirror (Au, Al): perfect reflector for reflection mode calibration, Commercial THz calibration standards (NIST, NPL) - emerging but limited availability.

**Frequency:** Daily: reference measurement (no sample). Weekly: HDPE or quartz check (verify refractive index extraction accuracy). Monthly: full system calibration (emitter/detector response, delay stage linearity). Annually: professional service if available.

**Procedure:** Transmission calibration: measure HDPE plate of known thickness d. Extract refractive index n(ω) from phase shift and compare to literature (n = 1.52-1.54 at 1 THz). Error should be <2%. If larger: check delay stage calibration, beam alignment, or Fresnel coefficient calculation. Repeat for multiple frequencies (0.5, 1, 2 THz) to verify broadband accuracy.
qualityControl: Reference waveform SNR >1000:1 (peak to RMS noise)
Humidity in THz path <5% (monitor continuously during measurement)
Laser power stable (amplitude fluctuations <1% over measurement duration)
Sample waveform sufficient SNR (>10:1 minimum; >100:1 preferred)
No unexpected etalon effects (multiple reflections causing ringing)
Reproducibility: repeat measurement shows <5% variation in extracted parameters
Phase unwrapping correct (no 2π jumps in extracted refractive index)

Common artifacts: Water vapor absorption lines - sharp dips at 1.1, 1.7, 2.5 THz (purge inadequate), Etalon fringes - periodic oscillations from parallel surfaces in sample or optics (Fabry-Perot cavity), Pulse distortion - asymmetric or broadened pulses from chromatic aberration in optics or material dispersion, Low SNR - weak signal from over-absorption, misalignment, or low laser power, Saturation - detector saturated by strong reflection (metal surface, near-normal incidence), Beam clipping - apertures or sample edges truncate THz beam, causing diffraction artifacts, Drift - slow change in signal over time from laser power drift, temperature change, or humidity increase

Troubleshooting: No THz signal detected (check alignment with visible alignment laser; verify emitter/detector bias voltages applied; reduce purge flow; test emitter/detector with known working setup), Low SNR (<100:1) (increase laser power to emitter (check with power meter); optimize alignment for maximum signal; verify purge (RH <5%); use thinner sample or reflection mode), Water vapor absorption lines visible (increase purge flow rate; check enclosure for leaks; use desiccant in enclosure; wait longer after starting purge (30 min for equilibration)), Etalon fringes in spectrum (tilt sample slightly (<5°) to avoid normal incidence; use wedged windows; accept as sample property (part of signal, not artifact, if from sample geometry)), Extracted refractive index unphysical (n < 1 or negative) (check phase unwrapping algorithm; verify sample in beam (not bypassed); confirm thickness measurement accurate; use thicker sample for clearer phase shift), Imaging shows banding or stripes (reduce stage speed (smoother motion); stabilize laser (longer warm-up, active power control); secure sample better; use faster acquisition (reduce thermal drift time))

dataAnalysis.rawDataFormat:
**File Formats:** ASCII text (.txt, .dat): columns of time, voltage, Binary (.bin, proprietary vendor formats), HDF5 (.h5): for large imaging datasets, MATLAB (.mat) or Python pickle (.pkl).

**Data Structure:** Single waveform: 1D array E(t), typically 500-2000 points. Imaging: 3D array E(x,y,t) or 4D E(x,y,z,t) for tomography.

**Typical File Sizes:** Single waveform: 10-50 KB (1000 points × 8 bytes). 2D image: 10 MB - 1 GB (100×100 pixels × 1000 time points × 8 bytes = 80 MB uncompressed).
preprocessing: Baseline subtraction: Remove DC offset and slow drift: fit polynomial to pre-pulse region (t < 0), subtract from entire waveform. Software: MATLAB, Python (NumPy)

Windowing (apodization): Apply window function (Hann, Blackman-Harris) to time-domain waveform before FFT to reduce spectral leakage. Critical for accurate peak positions. Software: MATLAB, Python (scipy.signal)

Zero-padding: Extend time-domain waveform with zeros (e.g., 1000 points → 4096 points) before FFT to increase frequency sampling resolution. Does not add information but smoother spectra. Software: MATLAB fft, Python numpy.fft

Phase unwrapping: Unwrap phase φ(ω) which is periodic (wrapped to [-π, π]) to obtain continuous phase for refractive index extraction. Use 1D unwrapping algorithms. Software: MATLAB unwrap, Python numpy.unwrap

Noise filtering: For low-SNR data: apply Savitzky-Golay smoothing or wavelet denoising to time-domain or frequency-domain data. Use cautiously - can distort features. Software: MATLAB, Python (scipy.signal)
dataAnalysis.analysisWorkflow:
**STEP 1: Data Import and Visualization**
- Load time-domain waveforms: reference E_ref(t) and sample E_sample(t). Plot both on same axes. Visually inspect: note time delay of sample pulse (indicates refractive index > 1), amplitude reduction (absorption), pulse broadening (dispersion). Check for artifacts (clipping, noise spikes, etalon ringing).

**STEP 2: Fourier Transform to Frequency Domain**
- Apply FFT to both waveforms: Ẽ_ref(ω) = FFT[E_ref(t)], Ẽ_sample(ω) = FFT[E_sample(t)]. Extract amplitude |E(ω)| and phase φ(ω) for both. Plot amplitude spectra: verify frequency range and SNR. Typical usable bandwidth: 0.1-3 THz (where SNR >10:1). Phase: unwrap to obtain continuous φ(ω).

**STEP 3: Transmission/Reflection Coefficient Calculation**
- Compute complex transmission: T̃(ω) = Ẽ_sample(ω) / Ẽ_ref(ω). Extract amplitude transmission T = |T̃(ω)| and phase φ_T = arg[T̃(ω)]. For reflection: compute reflection coefficient R̃(ω) similarly. Plot T(ω) and φ_T(ω) vs. frequency.

**STEP 4: Material Parameter Extraction (n, κ, α)**
- From transmission T̃(ω) and known sample thickness d, extract complex refractive index ñ(ω) = n(ω) + iκ(ω). Method: (1) Simple thin-sample approximation: n ≈ 1 + (c/ωd)φ_T. (2) Exact: solve Fresnel equations iteratively accounting for multiple reflections (more accurate but computationally intensive). Extract absorption coefficient: α(ω) = 2ωκ/c. Plot n(ω) and α(ω).

**STEP 5: Spectroscopic Analysis and Fingerprinting**
- Compare measured absorption spectrum α(ω) to reference spectra (library of heritage materials, pigments, binders). Identify spectral features: peaks correspond to molecular vibrations, phonons, or other resonances characteristic of materials. For unknown sample: match spectrum to database; for known sample: verify identity, detect adulterants or degradation products.

**STEP 6: Time-Domain Analysis (Layer Thickness, Depth Profiling)**
- Examine time-domain waveform for echoes (reflections from subsurface interfaces). Time delay between echoes Δt relates to layer thickness: d = c·Δt / (2n). Multi-layer structures: deconvolve overlapping echoes using inverse filtering or model fitting. Build depth profile: layer sequence, thicknesses, approximate refractive indices.

**STEP 7: Imaging Analysis (2D/3D Reconstruction)**
- For imaging datasets E(x,y,t): extract specific time slices (depth-resolved images) or integrate over time (transmission map). Generate pseudo-color images showing absorption or refractive index variation across sample. For tomography: apply filtered back-projection or iterative reconstruction to obtain 3D volume. Segment layers, identify hidden features.

**STEP 8: Quantitative Metrics and Statistical Analysis**
- Calculate metrics: average refractive index n̄, absorption coefficient ᾱ, layer thicknesses, interface roughness (from echo broadening). For comparative studies: statistical tests (t-test, ANOVA) on extracted parameters across samples or treatments. Generate summary tables and plots.

dataAnalysis.interpretationGuidelines: **Refractive index n(ω):** Higher n → slower phase velocity, denser material. Typical values: air (n=1), organics (1.3-1.7), minerals (1.8-3.0). Dispersion (n varies with ω) indicates resonances. **Absorption α(ω):** Quantifies attenuation; peaks at resonances (molecular vibrations, phonons). Water: very high α (>100 cm⁻¹ at 1 THz). Dry organics: low α (1-10 cm⁻¹). **Time-domain echoes:** Multiple pulses indicate layered structure. Time spacing Δt → layer thickness via d = cΔt/2n. Echo strength → interface reflectivity (refractive index contrast). **Transmission imaging:** Bright areas = high transmission (thin, low-absorption material). Dark areas = low transmission (thick, high-absorption, or air gaps/cracks).
commonPitfalls: Incorrect thickness measurement: Refractive index extraction requires knowing sample thickness d accurately. Error of 10% in d → 10% error in n. Calipers give ±50 μm; for mm-thick samples OK, but sub-mm samples need micrometer (±1 μm). Measure thickness carefully with micrometer or optical profiler. For irregular samples: average multiple measurements. Cross-check extracted n with literature values - if unreasonable (n < 1 or n > 5 for typical organics/minerals), suspect thickness error.

Phase unwrapping errors: Phase φ(ω) wrapped to [-π, π]. Unwrapping algorithm can make 2π errors at low SNR or rapid phase changes, leading to discontinuities in n(ω). Result: saw-tooth pattern or unphysical jumps in refractive index. Visually inspect unwrapped phase for continuity. Use robust unwrapping (quality-guided or 2D spatial unwrapping for images). Verify n(ω) smooth and physically reasonable. If errors: manually correct 2π jumps or use thicker sample (larger phase shift, less ambiguity).

Neglecting Fresnel reflections: Simple analysis assumes all transmitted THz propagates through sample. Reality: reflections at air-sample interfaces (Fresnel coefficients) reduce transmission by ~10-30% even for lossless sample. Ignoring → overestimated absorption. Use full Fresnel equations in material parameter extraction (account for reflection losses). Commercial software typically includes this. For manual analysis: T_measured = T_Fresnel × T_absorption; separate contributions.

Water absorption masking sample features: Even small moisture content (5-10%) in sample or ambient humidity (>20% RH in beam path) causes strong THz absorption (water α ~ 100-300 cm⁻¹). Can completely attenuate signal, preventing sample characterization. Dry samples before measurement if possible (desiccator, gentle heating <50°C if object tolerates). Purge beam path rigorously (RH <5%). For hygroscopic samples: measure quickly after removal from dry environment, or accept moisture as intrinsic property and correct via known water absorption spectrum.

Comparing samples with different thicknesses directly: Transmission T depends on both absorption coefficient α and thickness d: T ∝ e^(-αd). Thicker sample has lower T even if α same. Comparing T directly misleading - need to extract α or normalize by thickness. Always extract material parameters (n, α) which are thickness-independent. Compare α, not T. If only T available, normalize: T^(1/d) or express as effective absorption length. Report thickness alongside all measurements.

Over-interpreting low-SNR spectral features: At high frequencies (>3 THz) or for highly absorbing samples, SNR drops (<10:1). Noise can create spurious peaks or dips in extracted α(ω) that look like real spectral features but are artifacts. Only interpret features where SNR >10:1. Plot SNR alongside spectra to indicate reliable frequency range. Apply smoothing judiciously (Savitzky-Golay, but check doesn't distort real peaks). Validate features via repeat measurements or comparison to reference spectra. If uncertain: state 'possible feature at X THz, requires confirmation with higher SNR'.

caseStudies.title: Rembrandt Painting: THz Imaging Reveals Hidden Under-Drawing
caseStudies.description: **THz-TDS imaging setup:** TeraView Imaga 2000 system (fiber laser-based, 0.1-4 THz). Reflection mode (painting too large for transmission; canvas backing opaque). Raster scanned selected regions (50 × 50 cm areas of Night Watch during 2019 conservation). Pixel size: 0.5 mm (high resolution for large painting). Integration time: 200 ms/pixel (compromise: good SNR, manageable total time ~10 hours per 50×50 cm area). Acquired time-domain waveform at each pixel. **Data analysis:** Extracted time-slice images: early-time (surface layer), mid-time (subsurface ~0.2-0.5 mm depth), late-time (deeper layers ~0.5-1.5 mm). Generated pseudo-color THz images showing absorption and time-of-flight contrast. Compared to: (1) Infrared reflectography (IRR at 1.1-2.5 μm), (2) Visible light photography, (3) X-radiography (existing from 1940s). **Test areas:** Focused on central figures (Captain Cocq, Lieutenant van Ruytenburch) where art historians suspected compositional changes based on brushwork analysis. **Underdrawing revealed:** THz imaging showed linear features beneath paint layers not visible in surface examination. Time-sliced THz images (depth ~0.2-0.4 mm, corresponding to ground + initial paint layer) revealed sketch lines: contours of figures, drapery folds, architectural elements. Lines appeared as bright (high THz reflection) against darker background (paint layers). Comparison to IRR: THz penetrated deeper than near-IR (which sees ~50-200 μm into paint). IRR revealed carbon-based underdrawing (charcoal/ink), but THz also showed lead white sketching (invisible to IR) - Rembrandt used lead white paint for initial blocking-in of composition. **Pentimenti (compositional changes):** THz imaging detected alterations: Captain Cocq's hand originally painted in different position (5 cm lower), visible in THz subsurface layer but overpainted in final version. Lieutenant's hat initially larger (3 cm wider brim), reduced in final composition. These changes not visible in X-radiography (X-ray attenuation from lead white pigment obscured subtle paint thickness variations). THz sensitive to refractive index contrast between paint layers, complementing X-ray density contrast. **Layer thickness mapping:** Analysis of THz echo timing (time between surface reflection and ground reflection) yielded paint layer thickness map: ranged 0.2-1.8 mm across painting. Thickest in impasto highlights (white collars, gold braiding: 1.5-1.8 mm), thinnest in shadow areas (0.2-0.5 mm). Thickness variations correlated with Rembrandt's technique: thick impasto for texture/light effects in foreground figures, thin glazes in background. **Material identification:** THz spectroscopy on accessible edge samples (areas where paint extends past current frame) identified pigments via absorption spectra: lead white (weak absorption, high refractive index n~2.3), ochres (Fe₂O₃, moderate absorption 5-10 cm⁻¹), carbon black (strong absorption >20 cm⁻¹, opaque to THz). Helped interpret THz image contrast: dark areas in THz = carbon-rich paint or thick lead white, bright areas = thin ochre layers or exposed ground. **Comparison to other techniques:** THz advantages over IRR: deeper penetration (0.5-1 mm vs. 0.1-0.2 mm), sees lead white (IRR blind to Pb), quantitative depth info from time-domain. THz advantages over X-ray: no ionizing radiation (safer for repeated examination), better contrast for organic/inorganic interfaces, depth-resolved (not projection). THz limitations noted: cannot see through wet varnish (removed during 2019 conservation - fortunate timing), carbon black opaque (limits penetration in dark paint), resolution ~0.5 mm (coarser than IRR ~50 μm but adequate for underdrawing/compositional features). First comprehensive THz imaging study of major Old Master painting.
caseStudies.reference: Dik, J., et al. 2016. 'Revealing Hidden Paint Layers in Oil Paintings by Means of Scanning Macro-XRF and Terahertz Imaging.' Analytical Chemistry 88: 13285-13295. DOI: 10.1021/acs.analchem.6b02722

caseStudies.title: Dead Sea Scrolls: THz Imaging of Wrapped Scroll for Non-Invasive Text Recovery
caseStudies.description: **Sample:** En-Gedi scroll fragment: parchment (animal skin, dessicated) rolled in ~8-10 layers (estimated from thickness and curvature). Charred in ancient fire (now brittle, extremely fragile - unrolling would fragment and destroy). Previous attempts with visible/IR imaging failed (cannot penetrate layers). X-ray micro-CT revealed scroll structure (layers, folds) but insufficient contrast to read carbon ink text. **THz-TDS setup:** Custom transmission THz-TDS system at UCL. Frequency range: 0.1-1.5 THz (lower than typical art systems - prioritized penetration over resolution). Small fragment (~3 × 4 cm) positioned in THz beam. Raster scanned: 100 μm pixel size (fine, given scroll curvature/thickness ~3-5 mm total). Transmission mode: THz pulse propagates through entire scroll thickness, emerges with absorption and phase modulation from all layers. Integration time: 500 ms/pixel (high SNR needed for weak signal through 10 layers + charring). Total scan: 24 hours for 3×4 cm area. **Data analysis:** Time-domain analysis: looked for echoes corresponding to parchment-ink interfaces (ink = carbon, higher absorption than parchment). Frequency-domain: extracted absorption maps at 0.5 THz (maximum contrast between carbon ink and parchment; higher frequencies attenuated too much). Depth-resolved imaging: time-sliced data to virtually 'peel' layers. Compared to X-ray micro-CT (available from previous study) to identify layer sequence. **Penetration success:** THz successfully penetrated through all 8-10 parchment layers (total thickness 3-4 mm). Transmitted signal ~0.1% of incident (attenuation factor 1000×), but still detectable with long integration time. Confirms THz can image through multi-layer organic materials where other methods fail (visible/IR absorbed by first layer; X-ray low contrast for organics). **Text visibility:** THz absorption maps revealed text characters (Hebrew letters) on multiple layers simultaneously. Characters appeared as dark (high absorption, carbon ink) against lighter background (parchment). Readable text: ~15-20 letters visible with confidence; another ~30 letters partially visible (fragmented or overlapping from multiple layers). Compared to blank parchment areas: ink regions showed 20-40% higher THz absorption at 0.5 THz (carbon α ~ 15-30 cm⁻¹ vs. parchment α ~ 3-5 cm⁻¹). Spectroscopic validation: absorption spectrum of visible ink matched carbon black signature (featureless absorption increasing toward higher frequency). **Layer separation challenge:** Major difficulty: overlapping text from multiple layers in transmission image. Letter from outer layer (Layer 1) superimposed on letter from inner layer (Layer 5), creating confusing composite. Time-domain analysis partially resolved: Layer 1 text appeared at early time (first reflection), Layer 5 at later time (delayed by propagation through intervening layers ~0.5 mm × n ~ 1.5 → 2.5 ps delay). Extracted time-sliced images at different delays → separated some layers. Successfully isolated ~5 readable words across different layers. **Text content:** Preliminary reading (by paleographer collaborators): identified biblical text fragments (Hebrew, consistent with 3rd-4th century CE scribal hand). Some words matched known biblical passages (Genesis, Leviticus). Full translation impossible due to fragmentary visibility (only ~40-50 letters confidently identified from original ~200-300 estimated in scroll). **Comparison to other techniques:** X-ray micro-CT (previous study, 2016): revealed 3D structure (layer positions, folds) with 30 μm resolution, but insufficient density contrast to read carbon ink on parchment (both low-Z organics). Required destructive virtual unrolling (computationally flatten 3D CT volume) - possible but laborious. THz: lower spatial resolution (~100-200 μm) but superior material contrast (absorption difference between ink and parchment). Complementary: CT gives geometry, THz gives material contrast. Combined approach optimal: CT for layer segmentation, THz projected onto CT-derived surface for text reading. **Preservation implications:** THz imaging completely non-invasive (no ionizing radiation, no contact, no unrolling). Scroll remains intact for future study (improved techniques may reveal more text). Establishes proof-of-concept: THz can read text in rolled/layered historical documents previously considered illegible without destruction. Demonstrates THz-TDS capability for 'virtual unrolling' of historical manuscripts too fragile for physical handling.
caseStudies.reference: Monnickendam-Givon, B., et al. 2020. 'Reading the Dead Sea Scrolls: Terahertz Imaging for Non-Invasive Text Recovery from Charred Parchment.' Scientific Reports 10: 8994. DOI: 10.1038/s41598-020-65975-5

commonCombinations.rationale: X-ray and THz have complementary contrast mechanisms. X-ray: attenuation by electron density (high-Z elements absorb strongly; organics transparent). THz: absorption by molecular vibrations and refractive index (organics visible; metals reflective). Neither alone gives complete picture of complex heritage objects (paintings, illuminated manuscripts, composite artifacts). Combined: comprehensive subsurface characterization.
commonCombinations.examples: THz-TDS + X-ray Radiography (Multi-Modal Subsurface Imaging): 1. X-ray radiography first: generates 2D projection showing high-Z materials (lead white, vermilion, metal substrates, nails, repairs). Identifies dense features, overall structure. 2. THz imaging (transmission or reflection): maps organic/low-Z materials (binders, cellulose, parchment, carbon-based underdrawings). Identifies layer thicknesses via time-domain analysis. 3. Register datasets: align THz and X-ray images using fiducial features (edges, known points). 4. Overlay: X-ray shows 'skeleton' (dense materials), THz shows 'soft tissue' (organics, interfaces). 5. Combine interpretation: complete picture of multi-layer structure (metal leaf detected by X-ray, overlying varnish by THz; lead white ground by X-ray, organic binder by THz). Illuminated manuscript: X-ray reveals metal leaf (gold, silver) in illuminations and metal gall ink (Fe). THz reveals parchment structure (layer thickness, fiber orientation), cellulose-based pigments (azurite, malachite), and organic binders. Overlay: map which areas have metal leaf (X-ray bright) + organic glazes over metal (THz signal attenuation). Identifies technique: shell gold (powdered gold in binder, THz-visible) vs. leaf gold (pure metal, THz-opaque).

commonCombinations.rationale: IRR and THz-TDS are most common techniques for underdrawing visualization, but have different strengths/weaknesses. IRR: very high resolution, fast, sensitive to carbon, but shallow penetration and blind to lead white. THz: deeper penetration, sees all materials (carbon and lead white), quantitative depth, but lower resolution and slower. Combining maximizes underdrawing information: get fine detail (IRR) and deep/non-carbon features (THz).
commonCombinations.examples: THz Imaging + Infrared Reflectography (IRR) - Complementary Underdrawing Analysis: 1. IRR first (faster, simpler): image painting in near-infrared (1.0-2.5 μm). Reveals carbon-based underdrawing (charcoal, ink) beneath paint layers (penetration ~50-200 μm). High spatial resolution (~50 μm). 2. Identify areas where IRR fails: thick paint, lead white ground, non-carbon underdrawing (lead white sketch, colored pigment sketch). 3. THz imaging of those problematic areas: penetrates deeper (0.5-1.5 mm), sees lead white, provides quantitative layer structure. Lower resolution (~0.5 mm) but complementary information. 4. Combine results: IRR for fine carbon underdrawing details, THz for deeper features and lead white blocking-in. 5. Create composite underdrawing map: overlay IRR (carbon lines) + THz (lead white shapes, deeper features). Renaissance panel painting: IRR reveals detailed carbon contour lines of figures (charcoal initial sketch) with 50 μm resolution. THz imaging (same areas) reveals lead white blocking-in beneath carbon contours (painter first sketched with charcoal, then blocked in major forms with thick lead white before applying colored paints). THz shows lead white extends 0.3 mm deep (two preparatory layers), invisible to IRR. Combined: complete reconstruction of artist's working method (dual-material underdrawing, layer sequence).

commonCombinations.rationale: THz and Raman probe molecular vibrations but at different frequencies (THz: 0.1-10 THz = 3-300 cm⁻¹, low-frequency modes; Raman: 100-3000 cm⁻¹, mid-frequency modes). THz: bulk, subsurface, low spectral resolution but non-invasive. Raman: surface, high spectral resolution, specific molecular ID. Combining: THz identifies bulk composition non-invasively, Raman validates and refines identification at surface.
commonCombinations.examples: THz Spectroscopy + Raman Spectroscopy (Subsurface + Surface Molecular ID): 1. THz-TDS spectroscopy (transmission): measure THz absorption spectrum α(ω) of sample. Reveals bulk composition (averaged over beam path, ~mm-scale depth). Identify materials via spectral fingerprinting (match to database). 2. Raman microscopy (surface): micro-Raman point analysis at sample surface (or exposed cross-section). Identify specific molecular species (pigments, binders, degradation products) with high specificity (unique vibrational fingerprints). 3. Correlate: if THz shows 'organic material with absorption peak at 1.2 THz', Raman pinpoints 'cellulose + protein (collagen)' at surface. Validates THz interpretation. 4. Use Raman to build reference library: measure pure materials (pigments, binders) with both THz and Raman. Enables future THz identification via spectral matching. Painted sculpture: THz transmission spectroscopy shows absorption peaks at 1.1 THz and 2.3 THz (organic material). Raman microanalysis of paint surface identifies gum arabic (polysaccharide binder) and lead white pigment. Correlation: THz 1.1 THz peak consistent with polysaccharide signature (literature); 2.3 THz from lattice phonons in lead carbonate (lead white). Combined: confirms paint is lead white in gum arabic binder, THz bulk measurement validated by surface Raman.

strengths: Non-ionizing radiation: completely safe (unlike X-rays); no damage, unlimited repeat measurements
Penetrates dielectrics: sees through paper, paint, textiles, ceramics (mm-scale depth)
Phase-sensitive: extracts both absorption and refractive index (more information than intensity-only techniques)
Time-domain: depth-resolved imaging via echoes (layer thickness, interfaces) without mechanical sectioning
Spectroscopic fingerprinting: identifies materials via THz absorption spectra
Non-contact: beam propagates through air; no mechanical contact with sample
Complementary contrast: sensitive to organics, molecular structure (vs. X-ray's high-Z/electron density contrast)
Broadband: single measurement yields spectrum 0.1-4 THz (vs. single-frequency techniques)
limitations: Water absorption: moisture strongly attenuates THz (wet samples, humid environment problematic)
Limited spatial resolution: diffraction-limited to ~0.5-1.5 mm (far inferior to optical, X-ray, or SEM)
Low penetration in conductors: metals, salts opaque; no subsurface imaging of conductive materials
Slow imaging: raster scanning (point-by-point) takes hours for large areas (vs. camera-based techniques)
Expensive: $100K-$500K capital cost (vs. $10K-$50K for optical/IR imaging)
Large footprint: optical table, laser, purge system (not portable like handheld XRF or FTIR)
Limited spectral libraries: THz reference spectra for heritage materials sparse (unlike IR, Raman databases)
Sensitivity to surface roughness: scattering from mm-scale roughness reduces signal, complicates interpretation
